posts.com:
Lately my attitude towards everything has been vastly improved, by choice. I'm saying positive affirmations a lot, am doing yoga, eating well, and generally have a more empowered feeling. This has been reflected in my dreams! I have more awareness in general, and more control once I become lucid.
The other night set the bar higher for me. I woke up about half an hour before my alarm, and decided to have a good dream for the remaining time. I lay in bed thinking about all the people I'm thankful to have in my life, and then proceeded to dream for what felt like an entire day, about going to a "waterpark" with my fiancée. It was sort of like the poolrooms, only outside, in the sun. Occasionally, I would get the typical worries I get while on vacation - is the dog being taken care of well, etc. But then I would remind myself it was just a dream. Literally the best dream I've ever had.
I've changed my tactic basically. Rather than becoming lucid and trying to teleport to where I want to be, I set positive intentions while awake and then go lucid in whatever place I end up. Guides in this general have helped a lot!
Last night I was exploring with some old classmates and current coworkers. One said something about the "other kids" getting candy. So I decided to find it, and voila, found the stairs leading up to the "candy room". I ate sour patch kids and M&Ms. The colors were so vivid and the sugar rush felt real. I think I'm in a childlike place mentally/spiritually.

Had a very short lucid dream last night. I'm a pretty regular lucid dreamer but it's still great to get them.
>reading sheet music in my loungeroom in preparation for a rehearsal
>the piece is real, "Ride" by Sam Hazo ( https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=au4geHy_S_0 ), but it doesn't look like how it should
>everything's properly legible but it doesn't fit with the piece as I know it
>look up
>a woman I don't really recognise is sitting at the table
>look at the far wall
>there's a bird cage on a pedestal and one of my pet cockatiels sitting on top of the cage
>waitaminute, my last cockatiel died years ago and I got rid of that cage when I decided no more birds
>I'M DREAMING
>there's a decent amount of resistance in the dream to me becoming lucid
>at first there's a small amount of doubt because of how real and normal everything feels, then things shift a little bit and I know that I was correct
>the light coming in the windows disappears like it suddenly became late evening outside
>the woman disappears
>get up and leave the house through the front door
>yep, it's pretty dark, feeling a bit uneasy
>a small insect buzzes my ear, looked like a fly
>grab it and it stays still
>90% sure something bad's going to happen despite my lucidity, which usually means something bad will happen
>reach the street and look down it
>there's a cluster of beautiful blue lights in the road a little bit further down the street
>as I get closer they start to form an emblem, which I was absolutely gobsmacked by its beauty
>took a good look at it so I could attempt to replicate it, but my skills aren't good enough in waking life to do it anywhere near the justice it deserves
>attempt to take a steam screenshot of it, even hear the click and even see the screenshot taken panel in my vision
>think to myself "There's no way that's going to persist after I wake up. A screenshot from a dream would be worldshattering"
>leave the dream an unusual way, feels like I'm being pulled upwards to my bed

for the ultra clear one? I became lucid in the dream, it was accidental
but I remember that I was sleeping disastrously all the previous days, only naps like that day(literally) and at that moment I think I had an alarm activated because I wanted to get up later to eat something... so i guess it was a bit of WBTB too

now i only have lucid dreams when i am a bit sleepy (not too much) i lie on my back and do breathing exercises focusing on it while i am listening to something on youtube at a very low volume
once I think I didn't even do breathing exercises and I only paid attention (a bit) to the audios I put on but I refused to sleep
other times I didn't pay attention to the audio (but still audio playing) but I did pay attention to what I saw in the dark
and other times the same but while I tried to move my "ghost" body (breathing exercises, you feel sleepy but then you start trying to move your body without moving a single muscle, as if you were preparing to move but you don't)... I think this was the most useful for me, now that I remember. I think I'm going to try again right now, I haven't done it in a long time.
the trick is to remain conscious but RELAXED to tell your brain or body that you are already sleeping while your consciousness is still active
Whatever you choose to do, it's extremely important that you do not move a single physical muscle or open your eyes, that's what all my successful attempts agree on

Well i find that very interesting and i happen to have one i captured as a adolescent years ago. this one is very red compared to the adults, it was trapped in the leg of a lander i made in the begining, the college wanted the specimen and later cut off all contact with me when college students came after me ( because their department spent millions on a ROV that failed 500ft down )

Here is the pic and this is all i know of them

They get larger the deeper you find them, the size of a ant at 400ft, about 4-5 inches or more as an adult at the bottom, as they age they become more transparent. They are extreamly focused at the fault line, at the fault line i have some video showing potentially shimmery water ( possibly chemical or temperature differential ) they run and jump down the fault line. I have a theory ( because of their massive populations ) that is they are native they might have a possible positive impact on the classic clarity of Tahoes blue waters.

pic is taken with a macro lense specimen is about 2cm in length, found at 1630-1650ft

>>33610016

OKay lol heres the story

I was 21, in the military and doing college part time. I wanted to see the bottom of Lake Tahoe but there were not pictures or videos to be found so i simply designed some stuff to achieve that goal and nailed it my first try.

What i didnt know is at least two colleges were racing to be the first to see the bottom of tahoe... also what i did not know at the time was they went to launch their multimillion dollar ROV and after 500ft they broke a fibre optics line, lost telemetry, and almost lost the whole thing from what ive heard. i know there were 30 people working on that and most were PHD.

Then what i also did not know is that they were doing this to get funding from NASA or work with NASA or somthing . i believe it was to explore a under ice lake that they were drilling through to ice blahblah..

Anyways im kinda not well with gauging peoples emotions and whatnot so when i first seen the bottom of lake tahoe it was enar thanksgiving so i sent them a postcard that read " Happy thanksgiving from the bottom of lake tahoe"....

posts.name: chase
posts.com:
>>33610016
I did this with no ill intent, i really expected them to reply" WOW great job congrats, we would love to use your findings"

but i guess i took away the title they wanted to be the first to the bottom of lake tahoe... at the same time i discovered the shrimp down there and the fault line

I was pretty bummed they did not think it was cool

Then i had students emailing me some rude stuff... then they got into my cloud storage somehow and posted my designs on the internet... but this did not bother me, i told them thank you and i would love to share my designs with the world so the rest of us normal people could explore tahoe..
then the news story happened on KCRA 3... the news mentioned that the college failed and confirmed with historians and experts that i was the first and dubbed me with the title...

That made the colleges more mad...
They gave up from what i understand

Then i got in contact with Christopher McKay who was in charge of NASAs anoulog research department he invted me to Palo Alto and told me they could use me in their analog research department... i said no thank you because it would involve me moving to SanFran and i really cant do crowded places.. i like the woods i live in.

Still talk to Chris though, really nice guy.

Now when i call colleges to get advice about biology or whatnot ( you would think thats what they are there for ) They dont seem to want to do their job, they either dont believe me... or question that my videos are from the bottom of Tahoe, i went to a college professor who was talking to a crowd about getting funding to buy a ROV to explore some places in california and i offered him infront of the whole crowd to use mine for free.... he basically told me to shut up... i then realized he did not want the information and discoveries,,, he wanted the money... and what he was asking for was ridiculous.

I just wish they would see we are both working towards discovery... its not a competition .

This is apparently one of the most famous videos of a nuclear bomb test. Apparently this nuke was an UNDERWATER one (that's important), apparently below the surface of the water, underneath a barge. https://youtu.be/MWBMImBA6jE

In the video above, it looks like it's something that has been publicly aired on TV or in some sort of video. Notice that there's a jump in the first few seconds of the explosion. This is important. Whoever published\aired this video has deliberately cut the very first second or so, the initiation of the explosion from the footage. In this way the footage looks much more convincing as some sort of super scary 'super weapon'.

However other footage of the same detonation exists elsewhere. Here's another video: https://youtu.be/YUd7tgIirBI

Now if you watch this video, you can clearly see that the initiation of the explosion starts ABOVE WATER, on the barge itself, as if the barge has been packed with explosives. But they claim that what we're watching here is a nuke detonating UNDERWATER. You clearly see a bright flash of explosion, so bright that there's a reflective flash on the clouds above. You don't see any 'flash' below water, just an explosion that seems to be directed upwards from the barge, as if they were trying to draw water into the air with the explosion.

No matter how many times I watch this, I can't unsee that the explosion takes place either entirely or almost entirely ABOVE WATER.

If a nuclear bomb detonated below water, in theory the initial reaction should be so intense and hot that it should literally BOIL water. Yet all we see is this above surface explosion.

This explains why the initial flash\explosion is missing from the Dr Strangelove Sequence and the first video link I've posted.

My thoughts on the movie was I overall liked it. I am a fan of Dave’s work and think he’s pretty credible and even handed. Though I will admit he sometimes omits evidence or asks leading questions to make a maybe case into a 411 case. With that being said I think he is genuine in his motives and his work, even if he can be a kind of goofy fox news boomer conservative. I don’t believe this was his strongest movie, and I think he would have to 2x the length and budget to really get the point across. I felt if he focused on purely wyoming cases and left out the Elk abduction, the BC case, and the Arizona case he could have made a stronger point. I know he was trying to drive home the German abductee case, but he could have just listed raw data of German missing people.

I think the films structure was off, he needed to set the ground work with missing persons cases, then explain to the viewer the interdimensional hypothesis (vallee), and then execute on the pattern of the cluster map, elk, germans, etc. I was disappointed he didn’t show the cluster map with the aquifer in one scene.

With all that being said, he had some beautiful shots on location, and considering he funds most of this himself it’s better than 95% of paranormal so documentaries. This is a film for the initiated, not the skeptics or the entryists, i recommend sharing The Hunter with anyone wanting to get into 411 type stuff.

posts.com:
Love is funny, Anon.

My life has been tragic but also very full of love. I can not tell you how to find it for yourself, but perhaps my story will inspire you to be the very best you, that love cannot help but find you.

I did not find healthy, good, real love until i was 36 years old. I had a chain of sad failed relationships with women who drew me with many charms. Some were very sexy, some were cool dude bro chicks, several were incredibly smart. The last one was incredibly smart. Her father had raped her for 26 years. She was a broken woman and i loved her more than i have words to describe. And she loved me too. It was so real, but so doomed from day one. Three years into our relationship, she asked for "space" and promised me we weren't breaking up.
She hanged herself 45 days later. Ruined my life. I lost my job, i hurt myself at a skate park, i lost my apartment, and my love died.
I moved back in with family in my 30s. I didn't work for 2 years. I just sat here on 4chan talking shit and trying to be good to others when i can. I played vidya, i stopped self caring, i just smoked a lot of weed ar grandma's house and gave up.

Throughout the past 5 years, a girl i knew in middle school started sending me facebook messages. One day about two months ago, she tells me she wants a child. She wants to move home 3000 miles and be with me.
Red flags galore.

She was a whore for 15 years. A stripper too. Smoked crack, did ice, all that crazy shit.

I said fuck it. Truth is, i was planning to just go die alone in the woods like the animal i had become. She packed her life into four suitcases and moved into my grandma's with me. No joke.

We're now deeply in love. It's actually beautiful how perfectly our broken lives fit together and found home. We're getting our own place this next month.

Love finds you when you are ready, Anon. It sounds stupid, but it is the truth.

That girl made fun of me in 6th grade. Hurt my feelings. Now she blows me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm going to add my few cents to the mix...

Some will tell you that true love is supposed to come easy. There's no forcing it to happen. And they, I believe, are right.

However... I think some also confuse "come easy" with convenience and "forcing it" with putting in the work/effort.

I found that true love doesn't give a shit about convenience. It doesn't remove the obstacles one must go through. It however does make it easier to confront the obstacles and put in the work.

Some things come more easily to others. So the prospect of true love landing in one's lap isn't unlikely. But in my experience it requires effort. And no matter how easily it comes, it's going to take effort and humility. As it takes two to tango, it also requires mutual effort. There's always the option to go with convenience. Or to ignore companionship/love altogether. For both parties.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
And I'll add that I don't blame anyone that goes with the path of least resistance.

If someone were to move in the same apartment complex as I and we clicked enough (+ she showed interest), I can't say that wouldn't be tempting. Even knowing there's someone else that I know no one will compare to. A person that feels like home and my soul lights up for like no other.

With there being no direct desire or interest in the person I feel is a true love, it would be really hard not to go for that. Like desiring a nourishing meal but one would have to put in effort to get it. Where as one could also just pick up a cheap hot and ready pizza. The latter will fill ya up and keep you sated. But ultimately it'll leave you feeling empty.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
One more post, I have a lot to say on this particular subject but I didn't want to do one long post...

Also, just some bits of unsolicited advice from my own perspective...

- If finding true love is something that is important to you. Then it should surely be a goal to pursue. I agree with those that said don't go looking for it. Be open to it and it will find you. And it shouldn't be one's only goal in life. Even if, there's a lot of inner work and self-love that needs to be focused on in order to allow that true love to flourish and grow.

- True love doesn't mean it's going to be any less painful. It's going to cause you to face your inner shadows and trauma conditioning. And that doesn't feel pleasant. It's going to make you aware of faults/triggers/bad habits that you wouldn't likely normally run into if not seeking an honest connection. And as far as I can tell, there's no end to it. It likely gets easier with both parties working through it together. But that also brings with it the awkward and uncomfortable feelings of being vulnerable, direct, and non-confrontational.

- Don't be afraid to show love. Not just with someone you consider your true love but with people you love in general. The world can be a cold lonely place and those feelings you might think are too much or will be received poorly aren't doing any good kept to oneself.

Today people may consider it comparatively harmless to elaborate only those automatic, lifeless thoughts which arise in connection with the mineral world and the mineral nature of plant, animal and man. >Dionysian imitatio is the influential literary method of imitation as formulated by Greek author Dionysius of Halicarnassus in the first century BCE, which conceived it as the rhetoric practice of emulating, adaptating, reworking and enriching a source text by an earlier author. When forty winters shall besiege thy brow
And dig deep trenches in thy beauty’s field,

Where all the treasure of thy lusty days—

Were an all-eating shame and thriftless praise.
How much more praise deserved thy beauty’s use
If thou couldst answer "This fair child of mine
Shall sum my count and make my old excuse",
Proving his beauty by succession thine.
This were to be new made when thou art old,
And see thy blood warm when thou feel’st it cold.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Schizophrenia or divided mind is a theory of psychosis instead of neurosis.
The theory says parts of your brain will withhold information from other parts of your brain and be distrustful after trauma or failure, or something like that. The more superficial rational mind can suppress the deeper instinctive mind when it needs to, for clear thinking, and likewise the second can interrupt the first in life or death situations.
What happens is constant suppression causes neglect and in time there are attempts of more direct communication, which is what these schizophrenic hallucinations are about.
Still, you shouldn't simply ignore them, nor simply do as they tell you, but maintain your rational role and interpret the communicated needs/wants...

posts.name: MercuryAttack
posts.com:
>>33610978
My first psychotic break came after a combination of not sleeping for a week, and the "initial consideration" that the television had taken a direct interest in me.

At first the experience was extreme elation, but as the delusions mounted, it turned into the most paranoid fear for my life I ever had -- long story short, it was only by extreme luck that nothing "triggered" a violent reaction out of me that day, especially when the police eventually showed up because I was... PUBLICALLY ALARMING A LOT OF PEOPLE. A lot of people aren't so lucky, the cops show up, and one violent thing leads to another.

After that initial episode of "acute florid psychosis" came two months of painful clinical depression. See, the happy stim neurotransmitters go apeshit for days during psychosis, and then you're left with a severe deficit of them -- not a fun time.

I'm quite sure I have never had wholesale HALLUCINATIONS -- seeing or hearing things that aren't there -- but that idea that set me off to begin with, "suggestive" talk from TV and radio, never really go away.

"Do they know who I am? How? Why?" If I thought about it too long too deeply, it was usually cause for more paranoia, more psychosis, back to the hospital. Now I just keep those ideas at arm's length... most the time. The things I used to be scared of the most did not come to pass, so I choose not to accept the fear or the "threats" like I used to.

After a long time of wrestling with the delusions, I have enough "insight" about what kind of thinking is straight up irrational and will only fuel another psychotic episode -- last one was early 2009.

But I'm aware in changes to my personality. I used to be a lot more emotionally insular. I used to worry about random people's perception of me. I used to be very obsessive about some things to just tune out the outside world because I was mostly disinterested and resentful of nonsense.

I've learned to roll with a lot of punches over the years. A lot.

Further, I don't really feel like 'me' anymore. I feel like I'm just occupying a vessel that is completely apart from me. Like I have been attached to a foreign flesh suit but am only realizing it for the first time. But this also hurts, because I know that it's what I am.

The idea of "oneness" also is terrifying to me. That I may be the only conscious being, endlessly living in fable worlds created by my own consciousness to escape the impentrable question of my own existence, and being. In that I am solipsistic.

I keep trying to draw myself back to Christianity, the faith I held deeply as a youth. But I feel hollow inside. It no longer deeply moves me, and in congregations I feel out of place. Once again I am made to be an outsider looking in, and what's worse is I can't even deduce what objective reality may be at this point. Am I the grand architect of my own suffering? What is the point of suffering in itself? To merely experience suffering for it's own sake does not sound acceptable to me. I desperately seek to find some kind of moral bedrock to tether me back to this reality and the human experience. Or is it that these experiences have been demonic deceptions to disrupt my connection to the True Creator? That leads to even darker questions.

I cannot make sense of these things. I truly felt I was not ready to handle this, and I don't think any of us can really handle it. I don't know what do to.

Liminality:
>is the quality of ambiguity or disorientation that occurs in the middle stage of a rite of passage, when participants no longer hold their pre-ritual status but have not yet begun the transition to the status they will hold when the rite is complete.[2] During a rite's liminal stage, participants "stand at the threshold"[3] between their previous way of structuring their identity, time, or community, and a new way (which completing the rite establishes).

>More recently, usage of the term has broadened to describe political and cultural change as well as rites.[5][6] During liminal periods of all kinds, social hierarchies may be reversed or temporarily dissolved, continuity of tradition may become uncertain, and future outcomes once taken for granted may be thrown into doubt.[7] The dissolution of order during liminality creates a fluid, malleable situation that enables new institutions and customs to become established.

posts.com:
Most of the time these things have no effect on me, not sure why that is. It's like my brain can't get into that imaginative space anymore where I imagine myself in the 'world' of the image.

That said I think I might understand the feeling that's involved here. When I was like 6 my best friend left and I remember going home and standing in the backyard alone, it was sunny but quiet and cool and I remember standing there getting goosebumps and just feeling almost a form of pleasure in my body at the shift in perspective thinking that this 'time' with my friend was gone now and wouldn't be coming back.

There was also this time back in early 2011 when my family moved to another city but left me staying at the family home a while (it was rented) till I could get a place, it was summer and I suddenly had the house all to myself - two pets had recently died also so it was just me and one remaining pet. I was spending a lot of time on r9k in 2010 and then it was banned suddenly, so I was a NEET, alone with nobody in the world who knew me, and even that place of connection had suddenly disappeared, so I was totally alone, but I was happy and enjoying myself reading. The sunlight would stream in with a very sort of reddish hue in the afternoon and the stillness and peace was so beautiful and sacred, I often get almost like 'flashbacks' to my time there for a few months.

I returned to r9k and spent some more time there, and felt more connection and so on - then the culture changed and I found myself feeling alienated and alone and so I'd go back to the archives a fair bit and get this sense of the hauntedness of this 'space', even though it wasn't even a 'space' at all. It's weird the disconnect between visiting a 'live' site and visiting the archives - technically there should be no meaningful difference in experience apart from the interactivity of communication. Again I would get this beautiful, sad, nostalgic, haunted feeling.

The androgyne has the word Rebis (double thing) embroidered on his garment, and on the head of the dragon rests the phylactery dictated by Ego sum draco. The Rebis is understood as the first human created by God, in his image and likeness and consequently androgynous. God decides to divide, in this creature, his male half from the female. He weakens the human, causing each half to search, from that moment, for the one that complemented it. The Rebis on the dragon is a model taken from alchemy documents; however, you cannot know its exact meaning if you are not an alchemist. We can understand it as the reflection of the opposites in each body and the improvement, balance and perfection achieved through the union of opposites.

In this complex canvas, not everything is summed up there. The title of the work is the name of one of the seven archangels. Zadkiel is the angel associated with the planet Jupiter and the one that is equivalent to Thursday of the week. The woman on the left, who is dressed in the color of this archangel, purple, plus her opposite color, yellow, has the talisman of Jupiter with the word SATQVIEL around her neck. This woman raises her left index finger to show us the magic square of Jupiter that is carved on the back wall, and a tiny character who is to the right of the painting holds another magic square of the same planet. These squares are made up of sixteen squares that result from four horizontal sections cut by four other vertical ones. The numbers are arranged in such a way that the sum of the figures on any of their sides always results in 34. Throughout the entire painting, Valls reflects these same numbers with Hebrew letters with a numerical value from one to sixteen, for Therefore, the entire canvas itself is a magic square.

Insomuch as astrology is accurate, the 'accuracy' is not latently to be found in any pattern of stars — which remember, are based on the relative, subjective view from earth — but in the observers on the ground. And yet this 'accuracy' is measured, again subjectively, against the values, hopes and fears of the storytellers themselves, who are creating the patterns as well as their accompanying narratives. And a value judgement really doesn't get more tautological than that, does it?

Then again, perhaps every planet has its own astrological system, with an entirely different set of proclivities and potential outcomes, even if from their point of view Sirius is merely a butt-pimple on some figure its inhabitants imagine they see, drawn out point-to-point to form stick figures, their imaginations fleshing entire scenes and mythologies out from there.

Stranger things have happened.

posts.name: Autolycus
posts.com:
Nature does seem to show a coherent congruence of archetypal strata from star to electron, with all of cosmic culture and humanity in between. Astrology as a method of representing those relations may be applied with some accuracy to human lives, but astrology is neither a physical science like astronomy nor a social science like psychology. Astrology is a metaphysical branch of cosmology that models the primordial formative evolutionary relationships between celestial bodies, which include human lives. Not to be judged on petty grounds of horoscopes or social facts like how an Aries person should typically behave or react, but by the relations expressed between the natural elements I would refer to ontologically as 'eternal objects', and what these relations mean.

Like how the archetypal formative of the letter 'E' is the existential formative of the constellation Aries, and how they evolve alongside the archetypal formative of 'N' and Scorpio. Just looking at their symbols, we see the instantaneous archetypal life of Aries turn to the continuous existential life of Scorpio. This whole process is repeated in the evolution of language to include nouns. In Gematria, E(Hay) and N(Nun/Noun) are 5 and 50; reaching the cosmic 500 is a bit too complex to elaborate here, involving the evolution from K(Kaf) to U(Final Kaf), which are 20 and 500 respectively. It all logically d/evolves more into mathematics and physics than sociology and psychology.

>>33588971
The laws of physics are just math equations, and a lot of them have seemingly arbitrary constants. It is possible to imagine universes in which the equations are slightly different - where a constant is 6.6744 x 10^11 instead of 6.6743 x 10^11, for example. Yet, when one starts examining the repercussions of these changes, one finds again and again that virtually any other set of constants and equations produces worlds that are simply unable to host intelligent life. Everything collapses into a black hole, or stars never shine, or everything collapses into radioactive dust. As the universe seems to be something of a one-off - and our modern understanding of physics tells us that any of these other combinations *might* have come to pass after the big bang - a lot of people conclude that the sheer unlikelihood of our existence is proof that the universe was designed this way.
Personally, I think it suggests that our incomplete understanding of physics will eventually reveal that many of these seemingly independent variables were actually connected all along (in the way that the length of two sides of a right triangle dictate the length of the third side) and that as such the odds of this particular universe were much higher than they currently seem because many of the inhospitable possibilities were never valid in the first place. But that's just my opinion.

My opinion: Western atheism in particular is intellectually weak due to the fact that it usually constitutes a rejection of specific articulations of the numinous (most often abrahamistic ideations of 'god', and occasionally expanded to other mythic, historical pantheons) and this rejection is often based on literalistic rather than symbolic readings of source materials. And while many atheists will say that they outright reject any and all notions of deity, they would be hard pressed to articulate every potential variation of what might constitute 'deity' — or even offer a survey of every historic articulation of what constitutes deity.

So insomuch as an 'atheist' can articulate which specific ideations of deity they reject, and why, then I certainly can respect their position on their specific terms if it is well-reasoned; but as a blanket default position, atheism strikes me as the reactionary, somewhat dim-witted younger sibling of agnosticism.

But that's just my take. Cheers.
